results.content: This is a great course. It's not for a beginner. You will want to know some react and the basics of node, express, mongoDB and mongoose before starting. I have done a lot of tutorial classes but this class is different. In the average coding class you might build a superficial/small project to illustrate some of the principles of a language or technology. This class is a substantially sized project that will show you how to do a huge number of things. The parts of the app are similar to each other but slightly different. This allows you to see how to use the tools in react or mongoose to approach a problem in different ways. For example, creating a regular user profile for vs creating an admin profile that requires extra security measures. I think what this course helped me the most with was all the little bits of things that you don't see by making tiny projects. When you make a bigger project you have to connect all the parts and there really aren't a lot of classes that cover that. Ryan is clearly very knowledgeable on the subject and I highly recommend this course.

This class is a substantially sized project that will show you how to do a huge number of things. The parts of the app are similar to each other but slightly different. I think what this course helped me the most with was all the little bits of things that you don't see by making tiny projects. Ryan is clearly very knowledgeable on the subject and I highly recommend this course.

It's a good course. Instructor explains a lot of what he's doing. He uses some strategies that area bit clumsy (express-validator 6 works differently, using arrays, removing lots of clutter; crypto is known to be not-as-secure as bcryptjs. Also bcryptjs is easier to use than crypto. Less code for the same results). Everything else is nice. I'm learning a lot of new things and understanding some old stuff from other courses.

Congrats!

results.content: I have purchase many courses on web development with Udemy. Some instructors I found engaging, others not so much. For someone new to JavaScript, the method is certainly in the details. Some instructors give you the barest of information and then ask you to wrack your brain for days on end while you figure it out. (It was a back tic, not a quotation mark. ) Perhaps that was their learning method coming up. As a photographer, I wouldn't allow a student to go out on a fantastic shoot with me without reminding them to not only bring film or an SD card but also make sure the camera is loaded. Yes, it happens. This is my third ecommerce course with Udemy and it has been excellent. The functionality and look and feel of the app is on par with many other independent retailers. You're not going to generate credit card sales from strangers who have never heard of you with an unprofessional looking design. It scares people and looks dodgy. I rated Ryan a 4.5 because unlike Basir, he only provided the final code instead of push requests after every chapter. If I tried to copy a block of code without having done the requisite chapters and components, I would be just as lost. I spent more time on diffchecker than I care to admit. Many students commented in the Q & A about JWT, cookies, and localStorage, etc. These are fair comments because we don't want to be hacked and have our clients blame us for exposing their financial details. This is an absolute must and I feel additional security protocols could be offered by the instructors.  I have learned a lot of good information and will continue to do my homework. Thanks, Dixon
results.content_html: I have purchase many courses on web development with Udemy. Some instructors I found engaging, others not so much. For someone new to JavaScript, the method is certainly in the details. Some instructors give you the barest of information and then ask you to wrack your brain for days on end while you figure it out. (It was a back tic, not a quotation mark. ) Perhaps that was their learning method coming up. As a photographer, I wouldn't allow a student to go out on a fantastic shoot with me without reminding them to not only bring film or an SD card but also make sure the camera is loaded. Yes, it happens. This is my third ecommerce course with Udemy and it has been excellent. The functionality and look and feel of the app is on par with many other independent retailers. You're not going to generate credit card sales from strangers who have never heard of you with an unprofessional looking design. It scares people and looks dodgy. I rated Ryan a 4.5 because unlike Basir, he only provided the final code instead of push requests after every chapter. If I tried to copy a block of code without having done the requisite chapters and components, I would be just as lost. I spent more time on diffchecker than I care to admit. Many students commented in the Q & A about JWT, cookies, and localStorage, etc. These are fair comments because we don't want to be hacked and have our clients blame us for exposing their financial details. This is an absolute must and I feel additional security protocols could be offered by the instructors. I have learned a lot of good information and will continue to do my homework. Thanks, Dixon

results.content:
The application created at the end is good but the coding manner is very old. The author haven't made use of async-await or even promises for asynchronous coding instead used callbacks everywhere. Also, no state container like Redux etc.. were used, just simple ajax requests everywhere. 
Application was good but disappointed with the code.
results.content_html:
The application created at the end is good but the coding manner is very old. The author haven't made use of async-await or even promises for asynchronous coding instead used callbacks everywhere. Also, no state container like Redux etc.. were used, just simple ajax requests everywhere.
Application was good but disappointed with the code.

results.content: This course is very quick and to the point. I am already fairly experienced with React and Node/MongoDB. This course was perfect for me since I just wanted something that got right into how to combine these techniques to create a full-stack MERN application. For someone with little experience in React or Node it may seem a bit quick. However I watched it on 2x speed and blazed through it quickly and felt like I really got a lot out of my time. There is a lot of great information here and it's all presented clearly and concisely.

There is a lot of great information here and it's all presented clearly and concisely.

At the end of the course when publishing the site the tutorial becomes a little confusing and hard to follow (not impossible). If you want to learn and have a new challenge, take this course. If you want to learn from scratch, try to search for Node or React courses for beginners

results.content:
TL;DR
Buy this course if you want to build a very specific MERN ecommerce store and dont care if you understood how you did it

This is really disappointing. The amount of copy paste, code refactoring without explanation (Lecture 109 @ 5:20 as an example), "we'll just do this" as an alternative to showing people what functions and processes are doing... I can tell this was rushed and not properly planned because of how much back and forth there is with problems. Lecture 108 is literally a bug fix with the lecturers commented code from trying to work it out. Prior two the above examples, I was already annoyed at the courses layout and handling as it does not explain why things are being utilised.
results.content_html:
TL;DR
Buy this course if you want to build a very specific MERN ecommerce store and dont care if you understood how you did it

This is really disappointing. The amount of copy paste, code refactoring without explanation (Lecture 109 @ 5:20 as an example), "we'll just do this" as an alternative to showing people what functions and processes are doing... I can tell this was rushed and not properly planned because of how much back and forth there is with problems. Lecture 108 is literally a bug fix with the lecturers commented code from trying to work it out. Prior two the above examples, I was already annoyed at the courses layout and handling as it does not explain why things are being utilised.

results.content: i learnt lots from your course .thank you sir
results.content_html: i learnt lots from your course .thank you sir

results.content:
The course says that it is for beginners/all levels. However, if you are a beginner who REALLY want to learn the MERN stack, this is not the right for you.

The tutor copied and pasted a lot of things throughout the course which is not a great approach if you want to learn things and let it sink in. Repetition is very important to retain knowledge and not copying and pasting. It was really a pain to get through the course and everything seemed rushed.

I won't be making any future purchases from this tutor anymore.
results.content_html:
The course says that it is for beginners/all levels. However, if you are a beginner who REALLY want to learn the MERN stack, this is not the right for you.

The tutor copied and pasted a lot of things throughout the course which is not a great approach if you want to learn things and let it sink in. Repetition is very important to retain knowledge and not copying and pasting. It was really a pain to get through the course and everything seemed rushed.

I won't be making any future purchases from this tutor anymore.

results.content:
I've watched about 35 videos and I've got a lot of errors (even when I used source code). I searched in the Q&A section and I think instructor Ryan isn't interested in real help. Especially in the course is only one solution for one error - installing an older version of the library instead of refactoring code and using the newest recommended version. 
Moreover, the instructor speaks vaguely. His English is very bad, sometimes is hard to understand him. 

When I bought this course, I had one goal - watching videos, writing code from the screen, creating app and learning. This is simply goals... and I am disappointed of this course. By the way, the idea for course is really god. The stack too - node, react hooks, express... but execution worse.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I love this course, because I learned a lot of good stuff.

Ryan is a very good professor that shows everything step by step, plus he usually will answer very fast to any question.

This is the only full end 2 end course where I learned how:
- to add images with each product in MongoDB
- to add any product to card and implement Braintree Gateway to let the user to pay with any card or using paypal
- to add filters for each product that you want to find by price or category
- to make an advance search, to search in a simple way or by category
- how to login like a regular user or admin and how to make a dashboard for each of them
- how to make a CRUD(create, read, update, delete) any product

and a lot more.

I was looking for a long time, for a course like this. 

Most of the ecommerce tutorials don't show how to add a image in database, for each product and also don't show how to use a payment gateway, the most important things in any ecommerce.

Thank you very much Ryan for building this course.

- to make an advance search, to search in a simple way or by category
- how to login like a regular user or admin and how to make a dashboard for each of them
- how to make a CRUD(create, read, update, delete) any product

results.content: Mid way through the course, its going fantastic. Course is definitely for those who already have knowledge of the tech stack. It's an excellent course for people those starting out that needs a solid project to get started with. Highly recommend this course to anyone looking for a MERN project.
